item.title: Week 10: Predictive Modeling (SIG 2)
item.description: “All models are wrong; some are useful” By the end of this week we hope that you will be able to better understand and explain this quote. This week, we will be surveying predictive modeling in education using a combination of readings and tools to work with data. Let’s get started! Plan and Resources for this Week: 1. Take this quick survey 2. Readings Required: Brooks and Thompson. Handbook of Learning Technologies Chp 5.

item.title: Week 9: Social Network Analysis (SIG 1)
item.description: This week, we will be diving into Social Network Analysis as an approach to study the exchange of information. Social network analysis looks at various patterns of relationships between different actors and examines the availability and exchange of resources between them (Scott, 1991; Wasserman & Faust, 1994). The actors exchanging resources and information could be individuals or organizations and their relationships determine the kind of information exchanged. Here is a short video to help you through the definition of social network analysis better.

item.title: Week 8: 'Fun with Data' Hands-on
item.description: Data wrangling, or data munging, is a critical part of any learning analytics project. It covers multiple components of the Learning Analytics Model including the collection, storage, cleaning, and integration of data (see Siemens 2013, which we read in Week 1). Due to the quantity of data and the diversity of data sources, a learning analytics project often necessicitates data wrangling – conducted by humans – in order to transform data into actionable intelligence and systematic action (Clow, 2012).
